üåü What if curiosity isn't just a trait but a secret weapon for your business? Unlock the Power of Curiosity in Your Organization! üöÄ Curiosity is more than just a trait; it's a critical driver of organizational success. According to Francesca Gino's research published in the Harvard Business Review, fostering curiosity in the workplace can lead to remarkable benefits: ‚úÖ Improved Employee Engagement: Curious employees are more engaged and motivated. ‚úÖ Enhanced Collaboration: Teams that embrace curiosity collaborate more effectively. ‚úÖ Better Decision-Making: Curious minds make more informed and innovative decisions. However, many leaders mistakenly suppress curiosity, fearing it might lead to inefficiencies or risks. To harness the full potential of curiosity, consider these strategies: üëâ Hire for Curiosity: Look for candidates who demonstrate a natural inquisitiveness. üëâ Model Inquisitiveness: Leaders should set an example by being curious themselves. üëâ Emphasize Learning Goals: Shift the focus from performance metrics to continuous learning. üëâ Encourage Exploration: Allow employees to explore new ideas and broaden their interests. üëâ Ask Thought-Provoking Questions: Regularly pose questions like "What if...?", and "How might we...?" to stimulate creative thinking. By embedding these practices into your organizational culture, you can adapt more swiftly to market changes and external pressures, driving your business towards greater success. Let's cultivate a culture where curiosity thrives! #Leadership #EmployeeEngagement #OrganizationalCulture #ForeverLearners

This year I've written portraits of some female rolemodels in MICE for Meeting Magazine. After the pandemic, some experienced leaders left the industry. When business started to pick up, many young people joined and it brings a breath of fresh air. But it also brings challenges. The organisation of congresses and business events require KnowHow, attention to detail, understanding a diversity of corporate or institutional protocol, great handling of logistics. (etc, etc, as the king would say!) Underneath all of that, it requires emotional intelligence to deal with cross cultural issues. That kind of experience can rarely be learned at home or at school. In this series of portraits, powervrouwen (female leaders) give an insight into their paths and their succesformula. It was a pleasure to find that most powerwomen remain open and approachable. The gatekeepers-climate, found around some male dominated powerfigures, was almost completely absent. Could this be a signal of a bright future, where corporate communication needs not be like political powerplay? It looks like the democratisation of the work environement is starting to flow upstream. The interview with Dineke Philipse is a great example of a powervrouw who sets her example quietly but firmly, simply by living in truth to her own believes. Please use a translator to read in another language.
